pull_request.title: [WIP] Enhancements for Custom Domain Handling
pull_request.body:
Thanks for asking me to work on this. I will get started on it and keep this PR's description up to date as I form a plan and make progress.

Original description:

> Implement the following improvements for the handling of custom domains in the AdLinkPro repository:
> 
> ### Scalability
> 1. Allow advertisers to use multiple domains, configurable via environment variables.
> 2. Introduce batch updates for tracking links to improve performance when updating large numbers of offers.
> 
> ### Error Handling
> 1. Add detailed error messages for DNS verification failures, such as DNS record not found, timeout, or DNS server unavailable.
> 
> ### SSL Integration
> 1. Enhance SSL certificate issuance by integrating with advanced providers like Cloudflare or AWS ACM for reliability.
> 
> ### DNS Validation
> 1. Add an automatic DNS validation feature when entering a custom domain in the interface.
> 
> ### Enhanced UX
> 1. Improve the advertiser interface by introducing progress indicators for long operations like domain verification and SSL issuance.
> 2. Display domain-specific error messages directly in the list of existing domains.
> 
> ### Testing and Documentation
> 1. Write unit tests for CustomDomainService methods.
> 2. Provide detailed documentation for each method and interface, including usage examples.
> 
> ### Caching
> 1. Implement caching for DNS queries to optimize repeated domain verifications.
> 
> ### Code Optimization
> 1. Refactor methods such as updateTrackingLinksWithDomain to use efficient batch operations.
> 
> Please make these changes while ensuring backward compatibility.



<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

✨ Let Copilot coding agent [set things up for you](https://github.com/pronto1245/AdLinkPro/issues/new?title=✨+Set+up+Copilot+instructions&body=Configure%20instructions%20for%20this%20repository%20as%20documented%20in%20%5BBest%20practices%20for%20Copilot%20coding%20agent%20in%20your%20repository%5D%28https://gh.io/copilot-coding-agent-tips%29%2E%0A%0A%3COnboard%20this%20repo%3E&assignees=copilot) — coding agent works faster and does higher quality work when set up for your repo.

+    list and inserts them into the parent's children_nodes list starting at the given index.
+
+    Args:
+        parent_node (TreeNode): The parent node to add the children to
+        children_nodes_data (Any): The data for the new child nodes
+        index (int): The index at which to start inserting the new child nodes
+
+    Returns:
+        list[TreeNode] | None: A list of the created child nodes, or None if no children were added
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root")
+        >>> children = add_child_nodes_from_index(root, ["child1", "child2"], 0)
+        >>> print(len(root.children_nodes))  # 2
+        >>> print(children[0].parent)  # root
+    """

     added_children = []

+            child_node = TreeNode(
+                child_node_data,

+                children_nodes=[],  #  Use [] instead of None
+            )
             parent_node.children_nodes.insert(count, child_node)
             count += 1
             added_children.append(child_node)
 
+        if not parent_node.is_parent:  #  Update parent flag
+            parent_node.is_parent = True
+
     return added_children if added_children else None
+
+
+def pre_order_traversal(root: TreeNode, result: list[Any]) -> list[Any] | None:
+    """
+    Perform a pre-order traversal of the tree.
+
+    This function traverses the tree in pre-order (root, children) and appends
+    the data of each visited node to the result list.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to traverse
+        result (list[Any]): The list to append the visited node data to
+
+    Returns:
+        list[Any] | None: The result list containing the pre-order traversal,
+            or None if the tree is empty
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = pre_order_traversal(root, [])
+        >>> print(result)  # ["root", "child1", "child2"]
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+
+    result.append(root.data)
+
+    if root.children_nodes:  #  Check for None and non-empty
+        for child in root.children_nodes:
+            pre_order_traversal(child, result)  #  No reassignment needed
+
+    return result
+
+
+def post_order_traversal(root: TreeNode, result: list[Any]) -> list[Any] | None:
+    """
+    Perform a post-order traversal of the tree.
+
+    This function traverses the tree in post-order (children, root) and appends
+    the data of each visited node to the result list.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to traverse
+        result (list[Any]): The list to append the visited node data to
+
+    Returns:
+        list[Any] | None: The result list containing the post-order traversal,
+            or None if the tree is empty
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = post_order_traversal(root, [])
+        >>> print(result)  # ["child1", "child2", "root"]
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+
+    if root.children_nodes:  #  Check for None and non-empty
+        for child in root.children_nodes:
+            post_order_traversal(child, result)
+
+    result.append(root.data)
+    return result  #  Always return result
+
+
+def level_order_traversal(root: TreeNode, result: list[Any]) -> list[Any] | None:
+    """
+    Perform a level-order traversal of the tree.
+
+    This function traverses the tree level by level (breadth-first) and appends
+    the data of each visited node to the result list.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to traverse
+        result (list[Any]): The list to append the visited node data to
+
+    Returns:
+        list[Any] | None: The result list containing the level-order traversal,
+            or None if the tree is empty
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = level_order_traversal(root, [])
+        >>> print(result)  # ["root", "child1", "child2"]
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+    else:
+        queue = [root]
+
+        while queue:
+            current = queue.pop(0)
+            result.append(current.data)
+
+            if current.children_nodes:
+                for child in current.children_nodes:
+                    queue.append(child)
+
+    return result
+
+
+def breadth_first_search(root: TreeNode, target: Any) -> TreeNode | None:
+    """
+    Perform a breadth-first search for a target value in the tree.
+
+    This function searches for a node with the specified target value using
+    breadth-first search. Returns the first matching node found.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to search
+        target (Any): The target value to search for
+
+    Returns:
+        TreeNode | None: The first node matching the target value, or None if not found
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = breadth_first_search(root, "child2")
+        >>> print(result.data)  # "child2"
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+    elif root.children_nodes is None:
+        if root.data == target:
+            return root
+        else:
+            return None
+    else:
+        queue = [root]
+
+        while queue:
+            current = queue.pop(0)
+
+            if current.data == target:
+                return current
+            else:
+                if current.children_nodes:
+                    for child in current.children_nodes:
+                        queue.append(child)
+
+    return None
+
+
+def depth_first_search(root: TreeNode, target: Any) -> TreeNode | None:
+    """
+    Perform a depth-first search for a target value in the tree.
+
+    This function searches for a node with the specified target value using
+    depth-first search. Returns the first matching node found.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to search
+        target (Any): The target value to search for
+
+    Returns:
+        TreeNode | None: The first node matching the target value, or None if not found
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = depth_first_search(root, "child2")
+        >>> print(result.data)  # "child2"
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+    elif root.children_nodes is None:
+        if root.data == target:
+            return root
+        else:
+            return None
+    else:
+        if root.data == target:
+            return root
+        else:
+            if root.children_nodes:
+                for child in root.children_nodes:
+                    result = depth_first_search(child, target)
+
+                    if result is not None:
+                        return result
+

comment.body:
Using `queue.pop(0)` is inefficient for large trees as it has O(n) time complexity. Consider using `collections.deque` with `popleft()` for O(1) performance.
```suggestion
        queue = deque([root])

        while queue:
            current = queue.popleft()
```

+    Args:
+        parent_node (TreeNode): The parent node to add the children to
+        children_nodes_data (Any): The data for the new child nodes
+        index (int): The index at which to start inserting the new child nodes
+

+        list[TreeNode] | None: A list of the created child nodes, or None if no children were added
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root")
+        >>> children = add_child_nodes_from_index(root, ["child1", "child2"], 0)
+        >>> print(len(root.children_nodes))  # 2
+        >>> print(children[0].parent)  # root
+    """
+    if parent_node is None:

+        parent_node.children_nodes = []

     added_children = []
 
     if children_nodes_data and 0 <= index <= len(parent_node.children_nodes):
         count = index
 
         for child_node_data in children_nodes_data:
-            child_node = TreeNode(child_node_data, None)
+            child_node = TreeNode(
+                child_node_data,
+                parent=parent_node,
+                children_nodes=[],  #  Use [] instead of None
+            )
             parent_node.children_nodes.insert(count, child_node)
             count += 1
             added_children.append(child_node)
 
+        if not parent_node.is_parent:  #  Update parent flag
+            parent_node.is_parent = True
+
     return added_children if added_children else None
+

+def pre_order_traversal(root: TreeNode, result: list[Any]) -> list[Any] | None:
+    """
+    Perform a pre-order traversal of the tree.
+
+    This function traverses the tree in pre-order (root, children) and appends
+    the data of each visited node to the result list.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to traverse
+        result (list[Any]): The list to append the visited node data to
+
+    Returns:
+        list[Any] | None: The result list containing the pre-order traversal,
+            or None if the tree is empty
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = pre_order_traversal(root, [])
+        >>> print(result)  # ["root", "child1", "child2"]
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+
+    result.append(root.data)
+
+    if root.children_nodes:  #  Check for None and non-empty
+        for child in root.children_nodes:
+            pre_order_traversal(child, result)  #  No reassignment needed
+
+    return result
+
+
+def post_order_traversal(root: TreeNode, result: list[Any]) -> list[Any] | None:
+    """
+    Perform a post-order traversal of the tree.
+
+    This function traverses the tree in post-order (children, root) and appends
+    the data of each visited node to the result list.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to traverse
+        result (list[Any]): The list to append the visited node data to
+
+    Returns:
+        list[Any] | None: The result list containing the post-order traversal,
+            or None if the tree is empty
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = post_order_traversal(root, [])
+        >>> print(result)  # ["child1", "child2", "root"]
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+
+    if root.children_nodes:  #  Check for None and non-empty
+        for child in root.children_nodes:
+            post_order_traversal(child, result)
+
+    result.append(root.data)
+    return result  #  Always return result
+
+
+def level_order_traversal(root: TreeNode, result: list[Any]) -> list[Any] | None:
+    """
+    Perform a level-order traversal of the tree.
+
+    This function traverses the tree level by level (breadth-first) and appends
+    the data of each visited node to the result list.
+
+    Args:
+        root (TreeNode): The root of the tree to traverse
+        result (list[Any]): The list to append the visited node data to
+
+    Returns:
+        list[Any] | None: The result list containing the level-order traversal,
+            or None if the tree is empty
+
+    Example:
+        >>> root = create_root("root", ["child1", "child2"])
+        >>> result = level_order_traversal(root, [])
+        >>> print(result)  # ["root", "child1", "child2"]
+    """
+    if root is None:
+        return None
+    else:
+        queue = [root]
+
+        while queue:
+            current = queue.pop(0)
comment.body:
Using `queue.pop(0)` is inefficient for large trees as it has O(n) time complexity. Consider using `collections.deque` with `popleft()` for O(1) performance.
```suggestion
        queue = deque([root])

        while queue:
            current = queue.popleft()
```

issue.title: The logic for determining test status is incorrect. The condition `i < passed_tests` assumes tests are processed in order and all passing tests come first, but tests can fail individually. This will show incorrect status for tests that actually passed. Consider tracking individual test results in a list or dictionary instead.
issue.body:
The logic for determining test status is incorrect. The condition `i < passed_tests` assumes tests are processed in order and all passing tests come first, but tests can fail individually. This will show incorrect status for tests that actually passed. Consider tracking individual test results in a list or dictionary instead.
```suggestion
    for (test_name, _), result in zip(tests, test_results):
        status = "✅ PASS" if result else "❌ FAIL"
```

_🛠️ Refactor suggestion_

**Replace deprecated substr(), and guard relative size against division by zero.**

Also handles very small containers.

```diff
-    const newStamp: StampAnnotationType = {
-      id: `stamp-${Date.now()}-${Math.random().toString(36).substr(2, 9)}`,
+    const denom = Math.max(1, Math.min(containerWidth, containerHeight));
+    const newStamp: StampAnnotationType = {
+      id: `stamp-${Date.now()}-${Math.random().toString(36).slice(2, 11)}`,
       pageNumber: $pdfState.currentPage,
       x: constrainedX,
       y: constrainedY,
       stampId: selectedStampId, // Store the stamp ID instead of SVG
       width: defaultSize,
       height: defaultSize,
       size: defaultSize,
       rotation: 0,
       relativeX: constrainedX / containerWidth,
       relativeY: constrainedY / containerHeight,
-      relativeSize: defaultSize / Math.min(containerWidth, containerHeight)
+      relativeSize: defaultSize / denom
     };
```

<!-- suggestion_start -->

<details>
<summary>📝 Committable suggestion</summary>

> ‼️ **IMPORTANT**
> Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements.

```suggestion
		// Guard against very small containers and avoid division by zero
		const denom = Math.max(1, Math.min(containerWidth, containerHeight));
		const newStamp: StampAnnotationType = {
			id: `stamp-${Date.now()}-${Math.random().toString(36).slice(2, 11)}`,
			pageNumber: $pdfState.currentPage,
			x: constrainedX,
			y: constrainedY,
			stampId: selectedStampId, // Store the stamp ID instead of SVG
			width: defaultSize,
			height: defaultSize,
			size: defaultSize,
			rotation: 0,
			relativeX: constrainedX / containerWidth,
			relativeY: constrainedY / containerHeight,
			relativeSize: defaultSize / denom
		};
```

</details>

<!-- suggestion_end -->

<details>
<summary>🤖 Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In src/lib/components/StampOverlay.svelte around lines 58 to 71, the code uses
the deprecated substr() and computes relativeSize by dividing by
Math.min(containerWidth, containerHeight) which can be zero or very small;
replace substr(2, 9) with slice(2, 11) or better
Math.random().toString(36).slice(2, 11) and guard the denominator by computing
const minDim = Math.max(1, Math.min(containerWidth || 0, containerHeight || 0))
(or a small epsilon like 1e-3 if you prefer), then compute relativeSize as
defaultSize / minDim and optionally clamp it with Math.min/Math.max to handle
extremely small containers so you never divide by zero or produce huge relative
sizes.
```


comment.body:
_🛠️ Refactor suggestion_

**Avoid magic numbers for drag constraints; derive from element size**

Using -100 and -20 is brittle and can clip text unpredictably. Measure the rendered element (or maintain its size) to constrain properly.

One pragmatic approach:
- Add data attribute to the display element.
- During drag, query its bounding box and use width/height for constraints.

Diffs:

1) Tag the display element for lookup:
```diff
-  <div
+  <div
+    data-annotation-id={annotation.id}
     class="absolute select-none cursor-pointer hover:bg-blue-50 hover:bg-opacity-50 rounded px-1"
```

2) Use its size for bounds:
```diff
-const newX = Math.max(0, Math.min(canvasWidth - 100, annotationStart.x + deltaX));
-const newY = Math.max(0, Math.min(canvasHeight - 20, annotationStart.y + deltaY));
+const el = document.querySelector(`[data-annotation-id="${draggedAnnotation.id}"]`) as HTMLElement | null;
+const w = el?.offsetWidth ?? 0;
+const h = el?.offsetHeight ?? 0;
+const newX = Math.max(0, Math.min(canvasWidth - w, annotationStart.x + deltaX));
+const newY = Math.max(0, Math.min(canvasHeight - h, annotationStart.y + deltaY));
```



> Committable suggestion skipped: line range outside the PR's diff.

Arrow shows (4) here, but Highlighter and Sticky Note still display (8)/(9). KeyboardShortcuts.svelte remaps to 4/5/6. Aligning these avoids user confusion.


Apply this diff:

```diff
           class:active={$drawingState.tool === 'highlight'}
           on:click={() => handleToolChange('highlight')}
-          title="Highlighter (8)"
+          title="Highlighter (5)"
         >

           class:active={$drawingState.tool === 'note'}
           on:click={() => handleToolChange('note')}
-          title="Sticky Note (9)"
+          title="Sticky Note (6)"
         >
```


Also applies to: 272-280, 281-289

```
for Arrow, Highlighter and Sticky Note buttons so they display (4), (5) and (6)
respectively to match the actual keyboard mappings and avoid user confusion.
```

comment.body:
_🛠️ Refactor suggestion_

**Avoid division by zero; clamp defaults; replace deprecated substr().**

- Guard against 0-sized containers (initial mount/resize) to avoid NaN/Infinity in relative fields.
- Clamp default note size to container to prevent overflow on tiny pages.
- `substr()` is deprecated; use `slice()`.


```diff
-    // Create new sticky note
-    const newNote: StickyNoteAnnotation = {
-      id: `sticky-note-${Date.now()}-${Math.random().toString(36).substr(2, 9)}`,
-      pageNumber: $pdfState.currentPage,
-      x: constrainedX,
-      y: constrainedY,
-      text: '',
-      fontSize: 14,
-      backgroundColor: $drawingState.noteColor,
-      width: defaultWidth,
-      height: defaultHeight,
-      relativeX: constrainedX / containerWidth,
-      relativeY: constrainedY / containerHeight,
-      relativeWidth: defaultWidth / containerWidth,
-      relativeHeight: defaultHeight / containerHeight,
-    };
+    // Bail if container size isn't ready
+    if (containerWidth <= 0 || containerHeight <= 0) return;
+
+    // Create new sticky note
+    const widthDenom = Math.max(1, containerWidth);
+    const heightDenom = Math.max(1, containerHeight);
+    const newNote: StickyNoteAnnotation = {
+      id: `sticky-note-${Date.now()}-${Math.random().toString(36).slice(2, 11)}`,
+      pageNumber: $pdfState.currentPage,
+      x: constrainedX,
+      y: constrainedY,
+      text: '',
+      fontSize: 14,
+      backgroundColor: $drawingState.noteColor,
+      width: defaultWidth,
+      height: defaultHeight,
+      relativeX: constrainedX / widthDenom,
+      relativeY: constrainedY / heightDenom,
+      relativeWidth: defaultWidth / widthDenom,
+      relativeHeight: defaultHeight / heightDenom,
+    };
```
Additionally clamp defaults earlier:

```diff
-    const defaultWidth = 150;
-    const defaultHeight = 100;
+    const defaultWidth = Math.min(150, Math.max(1, containerWidth));
+    const defaultHeight = Math.min(100, Math.max(1, containerHeight));
```

<details>
<summary>🤖 Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In src/lib/components/StickyNoteOverlay.svelte around lines 45 to 60, the code
can produce NaN/Infinity and overflow when containerWidth or containerHeight are
0 and uses deprecated substr(); fix by guarding against zero container
dimensions (if containerWidth or containerHeight are falsy treat as 1 for
division or set relativeX/relativeY/relativeWidth/relativeHeight to 0), clamp
defaultWidth/defaultHeight to not exceed containerWidth/containerHeight before
creating the note (ensure defaults are computed earlier), and replace
.substr(2,9) with .slice(2,11) (or appropriate length) when generating the id;
ensure all relative calculations only divide by a non-zero value.
```

</details>

**Incorrect prop declaration: use export let, not export const.**

`export const scale` makes it non-bindable; parents passing `scale` get ignored.

```diff
-export const scale: number = 1; // Used for future scaling calculations
+export let scale: number = 1; // Used for future scaling calculations
```

```suggestion
	export let containerWidth: number = 0;
	export let containerHeight: number = 0;
```
